charter_schools.description: Charter schools are independently run schools that receive public government funding, dependent on meeting certain accountability criteria. Although mainly in the developed world, charter schools were/are extensively used in Chile, which is in the midst of transitioning from a developing to developed country. Assuming Affordable Private Schools are delivering higher quality education at a lower cost than public schools, applying the charter school model for funding could increase availability.

building_imagination.creator: 2bd631be8100fdb010ceb13eff76d74f

comments.text: Thanks Faris. Great work Meena. And Richard, wow. Very true. I completely agree.May our dreams (and our minds) never cease to grow.

The 'building imagination' idea is great; let's get them to imagine - but what if you sought to instill in them a sense of awe, wonder.Kids are creative, and that is because they're dreamers. Let's not limit them to honing the mode of their dreams, but the facilitation of those dreams. This could be done by not just letting them create - but by putting them in a story in the midst of their community (skit, play, et all) where they are part of that story. Then, they can take part in and relate to the fanciful story, contributing where apt. And doing so together, as individuals within a group is vitally important (Shared Resources and Experiences: Dhyaasa). Throughout a day you can tell a singular story like this and use it not only to stretch their minds, but also as a platform for teaching morals and social issues (Story-telling on Wheels: Meena Kadri). Their success is not simply affiliated with their ability to imagine and being physically artistic - but so much to their ability to stretch the possibilities within their mind and prepare them for the understanding of many paradigms.The focus becomes their mental and emotional health - as well as educational. And they are being actively promoted as someone who looks for purpose and dreams of something greater than them - a bigger picture - a story worth dreaming about.And hopefully they parlay that into the dreams of their heart for life.
Indeed Faris  from Sudan to El Salvador, I'm sure that children are creating their own ways to play everywhere. Here's some earlier images from India: http://bit.ly/awcn3u

I love that quote from Picasso. Its so true! Children are already doing this in poor rural cities in Sudan. The local children find scraps and garbage in the grounds and create their own toys. They are super creative and innovative. I think there is great opportunity to foster their creative potential. If someone were to supply the recycled materials to the local schools, they could use these materials to create art, mechanical, or science experiments / projects.

building_imagination.title: Building Imagination

Also hammers home the point that abstract knowledge needs to link to applicable things. eg. If learning about maths  can vegetables, grains or something familiar be used to illustrate and embody concepts?

Definitely true. There always has to be a desire for the training where it is made clear where the benefits outweigh the costs. While the curriculum in such areas will change over the time, the main goal of an education is to give someone the necessary tools to be successful in their own eyes. Immediate training and vocational training seem to pop up in my mind as well.
Also... did you check out Sally's post: http://bit.ly/dcpqUN ?And Vincent's http://bit.ly/cWAXIx ?Can we build upon these to propose applicable solutions?

Hear! Hear! Smriti. Gujarat's Barefoot College understand this well: http://bit.ly/dxt4nf They've got so good at training rural dwellers to use locally relevant technology (eg. their Barefoot Solar Engineers program was been so successful that they've been implementing it in Africa and beyond)

comments.text: Thanks Gabriel  I see from the links on your profile page that this is a specialist area for you  great to have you onboard! I look forward to seeing you applying some of this theory during the next Concepting stage.

Games are a really great form!  One of the really difficult problems with using them is that people perceive them as not being "serious enough".  This might be implemented easily for children, but adults often respond negatively at first when asked to "play" as a form of learning.  Perhaps it comes from this insight: (from wikipedia) "Wittgenstein demonstrated that the elements of games, such as play, rules, and competition, all fail to adequately define what games are. People apply the term game to a range of disparate human activities."
When games are used as part of larger discussions it helps structure learning activities, the ability to fail without consequence, and in promoting memories fo the future.  
Thinking explicitly about the elements of games is an incredibly useful exercise for students and teachers alike.
Some common ones include:1) agents and actors, 2) their objectives, 3) the procedures they use to reach their objectives4) the rules that constrain their actions5) the resources they have to accomplish their goals6) the boundaries of their interactions7) the conflicts that ensue 8) the outcomes of those conflicts

Thank you Meena. a good point from you about maintance ,I hadn't thought about it but you are right. 
About your link. On the right way, I think i imagined something that was more merged into the local society. More like a treasure hunt game maybe? In any case something bigger. If that could be something that not only showed and taught the skills, but also showed them in a real life application. That would give the kids a direct answer to the often raised question: why are we learning this?
Wow, low cast, adaptable way to make peer teaching/learning about important areas fun. Love it as well!

board_game_on_big_issues.title: Board Game on Big Issues

kids_creating_and_preserving_the_stories.description:
If you've listened to public radio in the US, you may know of StoryCorps. StoryCorps is an organization that records interviews of friends and family, providing people of all backgrounds and beliefs with the opportunity to record, share, and preserve the stories of their lives. It's a fascinating project, and benefits not only the people involved in the interviews, but the listener as well.

This concept will enable Indian students to record interviews of their families and friends, and help them learn English along the way, as well as record their fast-changing culture for posterity.
kids_creating_and_preserving_the_stories.creator: e570d4eb8d96d6a184300eb08e1c9e42

comments.text: I completely agree that it is incredibly validating for children to see their own stories documented and shared with others.  On top of that, the skills embedded in learning how to interview/tell a story are incredibly relevant to literacy- story structure, framing questions, understanding narrative flow, etc...We have been working on a similar project at the Children's Creativity Museum in San Francisco- you can see some of the early results here:  http://childrenscreativity.wordpress.com/zeum-stories/

kids_creating_and_preserving_the_stories.title: Kids creating and preserving the stories of their lives

centralized_english_language_learning.description: As a model for one of the ways schools could help kids learn English, there could be a service that centralizes expertise in English language teaching and learning that schools could connect to through the internet.
centralized_english_language_learning.creator: f6a81c29dd685bbe0e09eefcdf349f07

comments.text: In New Zealand schools the issue of broadband speed and wifi is an issue for access to the Internet. This is an invisible challenge to overcome in India. I work with children with English as a second language or new immigrants to New Zealand. A programme such as www.mathsbuddy.co.nz is working brilliantly to teach Maths and English. The children are picking up English while achieving in Maths. double whammy. This company should in my opinion be sponsored to take their Maths curriculum ( Year 1-13) to India. They have the values and high intention of special people. Pat and Steve Murray have offered their programme to Maori students in New Zealand for the past 5 years.A challenge they face is how to make this available and affordable. MacDonalds made the programme free to all their staff and to students throughout Australia for a while.The more I think about it, you should contact them. I have had the privilege of administering the scholarships to Maori students as part of my service.Talk to Pat Murray www.mathsbuddy.co.nz he is a very smart, humble man with a great vision. How to make it happen?

To think of a solution, when it concerns the Indian student population, is more to do with the local language rather than English, as much. In a country as diverse as India,  where the local dialects and languages change about every ten kms, I think, a better solution than internet english teaching would be practical teaching. Where students learn from their language using practical and interactive teaching methods. To suggest examples, Radio technology from the nearest and local radio station could help impart education to all those students who stop going to school after a certain age (since they start working with their parents in fields). While 'mid-day meals' could continue as a motivational incentive for students and parents, learning from home, would also be a great advantage.

there's just about one suggestion in this proposal...In Municipal Corporation Schools in India where the number of students in a class start decreasing with the increasing level of education.A "mid-day meal" (an initiative by the Government of India) is the only motivation for the parents to send their children for a meal that they will perhaps be able to consume (if they go to school). Now, how do we expect to establish something such as an internet teaching here?  Teaching 'English' in itself, is a far fetched concept in such schools. Since these schools are the prominent schools for the general public, I think this model will perhaps fail in India.
well done,

centralized_english_language_learning.title: Centralized English-language learning

one_laptop_per_child.description:
A rugged, low-cost, low-power, connected laptop with content and software designed for collaborative, joyful, self-empowered learning. 

http://laptop.org
one_laptop_per_child.creator: 84c04044b0796f3cedaff79875d9bbd5

comments.text:
Arturo,
I agree about the pencil divide, however, I think that the whole idea of "one laptop per child" was more about making it affordable for donators (and not local people) to buy laptops for children in developing and rural areas. And not just any laptops, but laptops that are specifically designed for kids, to endure outdoor use, dust and be powered by batteries that can be recharged manually or with solar panels (as seen on the attached video). It is more about smart and low-cost design.
In any case, this is just an inspiration :-)

Yorgos, 
The problem with this approach is that it is not about bridging the Digital Divide, when this is more of a Pencil Divide.
My sister has been managing the distribution of XOs in the Yucatan Peninsula in Mexico and I can tell you this doesn't "increase the availability of affordable learning tools".
If families live with less than $1 USD a day, how could they justify 3-5 months  of income?
This isn't the solution, but certainly part of a conversation where we can learn from the experiences of deployments as the XO.
genius

one_laptop_per_child.title: XO - one laptop per child

global_podcast_of_lessons.description: A service that gathers recordings made by teachers and students in schools of their lessons or lectures and stores them online giving teachers in APSs full access to their lessons. These recordings are then distributed via phone, internet, or tape/cd etc. for use in lessons, or as homework revision.
global_podcast_of_lessons.creator: d7d03fc4ed767b64ad78b2fdbcd6324c

comments.text:
Good idea, Nathan!
Given that a lot of learning content (especially in the lower grades) need not be that dynamic (i.e., updated very frequently!), one could even store a lot of teaching materials in an iPod or similar device and not even require the use of a radio station. The "appropriate track" could simply be played depending on the class the students were attending, and the content periodically refreshed. 
-G

global_podcast_of_lessons.title: Global Podcast of lessons

stone_soup_schools_all_ages_collaborativ.description: The moral of the story is that when a whole community comes together to pool their resources, they all get to share in something better than what they had as individuals.  Stone Soup Schools could be an ideal way to create community spaces where everyone can contribute something that they have in order to get something of even higher value, effectively becoming a local think-tank for a better world.  Stone Soup Schools can be open to all ages, to explore, test, and share ways to get more of what people need to be healthy and successful in life.  Having a practical goal for the school - to serve as a cooperatively owned community center that helps people get more of the basic needs in life for healthy growth, mentally, and physically - will give everyone a motivation to help support the schools.
stone_soup_schools_all_ages_collaborativ.creator: c09d9310c3ca89257885d8363f40c09e
stone_soup_schools_all_ages_collaborativ.title: Stone Soup Schools - all ages collaborative community school co-ops

The process of slow design is comprehensive, holistic, inclusive, reflective and considered. It permits evolution and development of the design outcomes. It belongs to the professional and public arenas and emphasises the importance of democratising the design process by embracing a wide range of stakeholders.

the_community_values.description: Create a community board of tradespeople that already have the real-world tools and processes to teach kids about science, math, and other subjects. Take subjects out of the classroom for activities that would be costly if conducted within schools -- science, for example, could find a new home with a baker, a dry cleaner, or even a housekeeper. This would educate kids and engage community members and give them a stake in the school.
the_community_values.creator: 018271c769550f277be5e7230b4eafc8

comments.text: This is along the best path.  If you create a trade/barter program for education and get education out of the classroom where in the US kids are NOT learning and back to real examples we can find success.  There are plenty of classes that can be taught about the basics of science, and math in learning how to cook.  You have weights measures, the science of adding heat to liguids, to make solids (baking) all those things are the basics of alchemy and science.  You could also offer a trade program for the teachers to give incentives to people to become teachers.  If you teach x number of classes you get credit to take x number of classes. Education does not end at 18 it is a lifelong experience

the_community_values.title: The community values

As a current college student in the United States, I run through a countless number of textbooks, novels, plays, dictionaries, encyclopedias and add to my "library of never going to read again". Further, I know countless college students who store their textbooks only because they cannot seem to find a good price for sale and rather keep them.

There is immense opportunity in finding a way and method to increase textbook donation and textbook recycling.
textbook_recycling_donation_as_a_means_o.creator: 77b7f34787db0cade4fb83dc859c1e37

unicef_s_school_in_a_box_a_portable_scho.creator: 87fd60e7f3edb4cb39ad0755583c33ed

comments.text: While the kit is definitely a good educational tool in emergencies that would help children to continue practising the basic skills in the 3 Rs, this cannot substitute the necessity of schools for children. The kits could be used as a standardized educational tool in relief camps and transitional settlements to continue with the education of children through non-formal methods.However, this implies that volunteers/ para-teachers that are appointed to teach children in relief camps are trained in the use of the kits; it is important to build up a standardized teaching method around the use of the kit.

unicef_s_school_in_a_box_a_portable_scho.title: UNICEF's School-in-a-Box: A Portable School with Life-changing Impact

partner_twinning_schools.description: Globalisation is clearly a contemporary topic that fires imagination within information transfer and tooling. UK independent schools thrive on all round extra curricular enrichment programmes for their pupils, and are registered charities. A superb strategy could be to twin or partner UK or Western schools with the less privileged. Clearly, developing a sustainable flow of information and or learning tools would be key. However, it is one that could enrich both in the relationship.
partner_twinning_schools.creator: 6ec48800d3415eb54aab1f9d198891bd

comments.text:
Harrow are already spreading their wings, with Harrow international schools in beijing (and thailand I think). Quite different to partnering with a disadvantaged school, but they provide precedent to the sharing of teachers, resources and ideas.
The Architectural Association (AA) in london where i currently study have made the point that the 20th century gave us asian students coming to study in top schools in UK and US, but now we are sending our best professors to them to teach them on their own soil in the form of summer schools. The AA had some 20+ short summer schools from rio to shanghai, in the middle east and even california. The world's best teachers went on a road trip. 
In that sense maybe the best primary school teachers could go out instead of sending inexperienced recent graduates.
I really like this idea.

partner_twinning_schools.title: Partner / Twinning Schools

a_new_way_to_learn_.description: The fundamental basis of this idea is that children should be their own mediators of learning (a ‘minimally invasive education’ method): through peer-learning much more can be accomplished than that through the ‘failed’ school. So it’s a project that reminds us that children have enormous potential to learn if only we give them a chance and that oftentimes, institutions can actually interfere in this learning process.
a_new_way_to_learn_.creator: 28890c0b3a775ebd22755c0a1a35b9f4

comments.text: There definitely will be a logistics and operational cost but it will be lesser than building schools or appointing teachers specially in remote rural areas. This problem could be solved to an extent by collaborating with government and maybe thinking up of minimal revenue generation ideas to go along with it .Even i had my doubts about the same but from the experiments and research that has been done it seems like kids in remote areas with an urge to learn do sit and play. I believe the newness of the technology is what attracts them to the station (as they are even unaware of what computers are). The possible ways in which kids could be retained at the station would be the way the interface and educational programs would be developed.http://www.hole-in-the-wall.com/Findings.html

Seems like we hit the "Publish" button nearly simultaneously! I just put up an inspiration nearly along the same lines. Perhaps you could update your idea with the TED link: http://www.ted.com/talks/sugata_mitra_shows_how_kids_teach_themselves.html . My only concern with this (as I had also voiced elsewhere) is logistics and operational costs. Secondly, there is also the question of the kind of learning for which this is suited. A lot of what we learn is instructional, would kids sit and watch a whole episode on chemical reactions or try and play something? Not a wet towel, but just things that we could ponder over.

a_new_way_to_learn_.title: A New Way To Learn

comments.text: Yes. This does turn out to resemble 'facebook' likes concept, but the idea of expression magnets evolved from the notion of people 'leaving marks' over a newspaper. subsidize_education_for_the_poor_with_hi.description: Healthcare in India is a shining example of frugal innovation. One of the characteristics is a subsidy system in which those who can afford it pay more to finance a lower cost health care for those who cannot afford it. One of the ways this is done is by creating large scale healthcare organizations. This system could be translated into education as well. Where institutions charge tuitions based on income of parents.

comments.text: Hi Gabriel, thanks for your comment. That could indeed be possible to use economies of scale so that everybody benefits as well. One could think of more experienced teachers at first. But other possibilities must be there as well.

One of the things I like about this idea is that something is gained in the ability to serve one group  while serving another group.  It makes me wonder if perhaps the model couldn't be flipped  serve the poor to serve the rich. This is also something that is being tried in healthcare  i.e. through the scale of serving the poor, gains are made in the service quality to the rich. ritual_schoolhouse_a_seasonal_migration_.description: The rhythms & rituals of life in southern India are set by the monsoon.  This schoolhouse, made of a shipping container and a bamboo "track system", allows for screens to be secured during poor weather, and opened wide during beautiful days.  I borrowed on Meena's beautiful mural / blackboard idea for the outside of the screens... providing an outdoor learning space.  The inside of the screens can be used for projection.  I was inspired by a Paul Rudolph house with a similar concept (metal track system) but wanted to incorporate low cost, indigenous materials.  I think it's important that children have space that inspire them for learning... spaces that feel open and playful, where they are free to move about and be physical while learning.

comments.text: I love this concept in that it cleverly sidesteps the issue of the high cost of supplying classrooms with enough of the traditional hard-bound text books needed for a class to learn.  The trick, I think, would be in funding the work it would take to transfer existing educational materials to the new format of newsprint.  Or to continually generate new educational materials (or refresh old content) to maintain a daily or weekly stream of resources for children to learn from.  But maybe this cost would still be cheaper than paying for traditional textbooks that become obsolete the moment they are printed.Utilizing the existing modes of distribution for newspapers is also clever.  Hopefully the infrastructure of roads, transportation, etc. can be maintained so that the educational newspaper can reach the most far-flung classrooms without hindrance.  Very inspired idea with lots of potential!

Interesting way to both lower the initial entry price for curriculum (similar to how companies sell smaller sizes of things like cleansing products in developing countries), and perhaps make content more timely/connected with current events. I think a big part in implementing this concept would be setting up sustainable content generation: hiring local curriculum developers, teacher-submitted lessons, etc.
I really like this idea for the simple reason that it adapts existing networks, resources and learning materials.  Here is another iteration of a similar concept: http://tinyurl.com/2co6387

comments.text: Great concept Sandy!  What if a motorcycle company were enlisted to sponsor the project? The company that supplied the motorcycles could film a documentary about the program and showcase how well their bikes handled the rough back roads and varied terrain of the Indian countryside (or whatever country it was implemented in).  Or even just to show that they are a multinational comapny that cares about education and children in developing countries, etc.  The same could go for the companies that would supply the laptops and projectors.  Get them to donate them in return for some great press!  Maintain the bikes from two or three garages,centrally located in university towns and hire university students to be part-time drivers to take the bikes and educational materials to the rural schools.  The students wouldn't have to be paid that much and the experience may even be applied to credit for their university course work.I think with a little creative sourcing and persuasive selling all the aspects of this concept could be assembled quite economically.Great stuff!

Sandy, I just mentioned to this in another idea. Explore the Science on Wheels by Agastya Foundation in India and also the Digital Study Hall project (http://dsh.cs.washington.edu/), they both something similar along the lines you outline. Your ideas certainly can augment/extend theirs. There is tremendous opportunity to provide such services across all developing countries so I do think this a highly viable scalable idea, with some good opportunities for a sustainable business model.

These projector cameras are a touch less expensive and will likely come down soon  running in at about 20kA bit less bright and with less throw, but possibly a good solution that could be coupled with other service offerings as well..http://www.nikon.co.in/productitem.php?pid=1376-9d9e77ec8e

Plus there are likely cheaper third-party iPad specific projectors on the horizon if you went in that direction.
Thanks Meena! Very helpful. A bit more expensive than i had figured.
Hi Sandy... worth looking here for starters? http://compareindia.in.com/products/digital-projectors/(just to give you an initial idea  quite possibly cheaper if dig around)

That's a great idea to make it an ipad... lower cost, and could also make distribution of new content (or new content clusters) to the local entrepreneurs easier with auto-updating podcasts and such. There could be local offices where the equipment is stored for people to come and synch the device. 
Curious... does anyone know what a digital projector costs in india?

Smart idea, Sandy! Excellent comments by everyone about how this could be made feasible.
Just as another possible approach, you might also have the option of an iPad + projector. Along with helping with the start-up costs, one might be able to leverage the work of companies such as Inkling (www.inkling.com) that make educational content specifically for this device. Connecting through Wi-Fi / 3G will be an issue especially where these ideas need to be implemented, so the teaching material might be *static* for a few weeks before the "Guy with the projector" can put new stuff on the iPad. However, this might enable you to get away from problems associated with unreliable internet connections / electricity and actually be a boon.
The projector might even be replaced with (not sure if this one is close to being practical yet so please feel free to shoot me down for this!) by a Sixth Sense-like device (Pranav Mistry, MIT Media Labs). Loading content on to a memory device of choice, this would enable using almost any suitable surface as a "canvas", thereby possibly further bringing down costs?

as to what organizations could introduce this service... i feel that if a corporate company steps up, the working of the program might be more smooth. for eg. a company like NIIT who already has a lot of ventures in the field of education and has a huge penetrating power.
When it comes to content, there are a lot of organisations with which tie ups can be made - Azim Premji Foundation, NCERT, Delhi School of Social Work.
Initial sponsors could be found in the form of Commonwealth, UNICEF, Michael & Susan Dell Foundation, SOS Childrens Village, Ministry of Education (SSA)

Hey, this is great thinking here! Thanks, everyone, for building on it! I agree that the motorcycle is not core to this... any type of transportation would likely work... the idea is basically that it's a shared service that can be brought to a bunch of different schools. Motorcycle, bike, car, auto rickshaw, foot... all good. All possible!
Business model-wise, i think there could be lots of different formats. Subscription, pay-per-use, etc. Not sure what would work best. Perhaps someone with better business skills than I (like Vincent!) can think some more about that. 
While this could emerge from any local entrepreneur and be great, it would be nice to consider local entrepreneurs as the front line for an organization that helps these "guys with a projector" have good content to share. Kind of like VisionSpring and their entrepreneurs, this business could create a "business in a bag" or "business on a bike", with the organization taking some of the investment costs, and helping raise up the local entrepreneur. 
What I think is fun in this concept is that it could happen in many ways. In its simplest form, it doesn't require expertise, and thus almost anyone can do it. To be more advanced, a more advanced organization and model could be designed.

Yup, for those who rent rickshaws, about 1/3 of that income is going to rental costs. Meena, do you know if there are any services in India that are renting out things like netbooks & projectors, or what organizations could introduce this service? I'm thinking a local entrepreneur, a partnership of schools, or a NGO/foundation could start this up, but perhaps there's something already out there?
Vincent  worth pointing out that most rickshaw drivers don't own their rickshaws. That's what I was trying to get at below about reducing barriers to start-up.

Given that rickshaw driver is reported as a typical occupation for the father of an Affordable Private School student (http://openideo.com/open/how-might-we-increase-the-availability-of-affordable-learning-tools-educational-for-children-in-the-developing-world/gallery/aps-info.pdf/), perhaps "Guy with a projector" entrepreneurs could even emerge from amongst the school parents.

Estimated Figures for consideration:
-Annual Rickshaw Driver Income: ~25,000-30,000 Rupees(below average Indian income but above government defined poverty level)
-Average Affordable Private School Profit: 641 students * [ (US$61 yearly fees per student) - (US$53 yearly expenses per student) ] * 45 Rupees per US$= 235,888 Rupees (US$ 5128)
-Key Takeaway: The Average Affordable Private School Profit is almost 10x the Annual Rickshaw Driver Income. Looks like if the expense is spread over a reasonable # of schools, this could work!
Sources: http://base.d-p-h.info/en/fiches/dph/fiche-dph-7718.html, http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Income_in_India, http://openideo.com/open/how-might-we-increase-the-availability-of-affordable-learning-tools-educational-for-children-in-the-developing-world/gallery/aps-info.pdf/

It'd be interesting to look at the income of rickshaw drivers/motorcycle couriers/bicycle messengers to determine what kind of revenue needs to be brought in for this to be financially viable.
Then, based on the density of schools in a region & the amount that schools are willing/able to pay for the service, we can determine whether this will be attractive to likely entrepreneurs.
Basically, to determine the sustainability for a particular time period: [# of schools reached] * [fees per school] >= [income of business with similar asset & skill requirements].
My guess is that this can definitely be financially attractive in densely populated places like Hyderabad where there are ~3000 Affordable Private Schools (a bicycle, or maybe even public transport, that'd be even lower cost than a motorcycle could work here; for instance, many restaurants in Shanghai deliver food using bikes).
However, the model may have to be adjusted to work in remote rural areas where schools are much further apart. Increasing fees from schools may be unfeasible & increasing coverage area (# of schools) has limits imposed by cost (vehicle investment, gas, range, time). In this case, additional revenue streams could be sought: such as using the projector at night for entertainment like displaying movies, providing internet/information services, delivery of small packages, etc.

the_university_of_the_people.description: University of the People is a tuition-free university. The University is a not-for-profit institution that does not charge students to take classes. Readings and course materials are available online, free of charge for each and every registered student. In the future, University of the People may require that students pay modest fees for submitting their application and for exam administration. These fees will be based on the standard of living in the student’s country or place of residence.

ship_containers_schools_around_the_world.description: Shipping companies haul millions of empty containers around the world every year. Other inspirations already illustrate how containers can be used as classrooms. The idea is to get shipping companies - who likely have offices in many of the areas in need - to sponsor containers and free shipping. A local community would then use a container for 6 months and then ship it off to somewhere else. In exchange they get a new school from another country. Make the learning experience global.
ship_containers_schools_around_the_world.creator: 4f33f60372e6bc655f12fa6964b669da
ship_containers_schools_around_the_world.title: Ship containers (schools) around the world

the_sharism_revolution.description: To really make education accessible to all we need a radical shift in mindset. For some time now education has been increasingly dominated by economic rationalism an ever more redundant discourse. There are a few voices out there who are making sense (sense making) on the mechanics of the post-capitialist paradigm we've entered in recent years (due to the GFC). Issac Mao is one of them. His discussion of sharism builds on the P2PU concept in a  number of constructive ways...
the_sharism_revolution.creator: adb6e47526372b8fd292f20be5bd4163

comments.text: Hmmm Brett... when I consider the context of poverty of the kids we're discussing I'm not convinced that it is a technological culture. Are there aspects of digital networking/social media that can be extracted into the analogue world? The P2P idea is fantastic but I don't feel that it needs to be limited to the online world. I gave an example on Ian's other post here: http://bit.ly/9ESQz9 (see comments section)

Absolutely, Ian. I think we're on the same page given your comment on my idea for an educational social network :) I think sharism will dominate technological culture for years to come, until people start putting prices on their data transfers (but, given the nature of the open source community, I doubt it will ever happen).

the_sharism_revolution.title: The Sharism Revolution

active_murals.description: Encouraging children towards creative play and active learning – mural-blackboard mash-ups provide an engaging site for customisation.
active_murals.creator: 0ebfe65ca16ea82675e4294e27747639

comments.text: This is such an amazing idea. I've noticed some of these active murals now in Mumbai (though they seem like they are community initiatives without much support from these larger corporations). It'll be great to see this idea resurface in some shape and form during the Creative Confidence challenge.

An additional way on funding this project could be through the creation of postcards or photos of the murals. If companies are to fund these murals, then they could use these pictures as their greeting cards, further increasing the potential of this venture on advertising the funding company. This could provide incentives for firms to engage.Love the idea!

I love this concept, and would love to implement it on a project I am currently working - an extension to a pre-school. If anyone has any ideas on specific artwork to create that would be great - the preschool is for 3-5 year olds, in Australia, indoors (using blackboard paint), not too much wall space (600mm high x 4m length just off the ground, at a childs scale), am thinking of using stencils. thanks !!
+ whilst not in a developing country, (we have a very low budget) and i just think this is generally a pretty cool idea !

Great Charlotte! Here at OpenIDEO, we hope that folks feel free to adapt concepts shared here to any context, developing or otherwise. We'd love to hear from you if you go ahead with something like this. Let me know here or ping me direct if you have updates. I imagine that something the children could relate to would be good  local plants & animals maybe? Or stuff that they recognise from their local neighbourhood?

I love this concept, both for its creativity and its hands-on approach to education. What if the murals were made of a concrete-like material that could also be "painted" on with water, so that kids could use it again and again (the water would temporarily darken the mural, and then dry and disappear), allowing for countless different creative activities, lessons and games?

Great idea, Lauren  I'm loving your build which allows for even more customisation. And we'd love to hear of examples from anyone out there who's used or is keen to try something along these lines to engage create, young minds.

Great concept, especially if the children are already familiar with murals as a medium for storytelling, information etc. This concept is scalable which makes it really appealing and could even extend to murals for adult learning too, perhaps in health education/HIV prevention etc.
What about transforming the artists into art teachers, organizing the students to create murals? Love the concept.
Great Idea - love the 'pure play' interaction between the children and the education and community building it can lead to!
This could be transformative when coupled with lessons in scenario-building and futurecasting.
Cheers Larry. Indeed  would be great to include maths-related activities in the Activity Guide.
I also want to connect this with the concept "Permanent, sustainable "Teaching Sculptures"" by Keane Angle, both great examples of using persistent information.

I like the idea of murals, it reminds of the purpose these large public artworks used to serve within churches, to teach the gospels before Gutenberg made bibles more available.
I would love to see a mural that taught something like algebra or geometry or logics.  Imagine a mural where by walking along it, you see and solve an algebra problem like "how many cookies are in this box if I share five cookies and have five left", or a mural that tells the story of the pauper who asked for one grain of rice one day, and for the king to double that every day, and how soon the king got into trouble -that becomes a mural of what geometric progression looks like.
Sandy pointed to the way of making magnetic chalkboard paint in an earlier inspiration: http://bit.ly/cJ7mHh. That could be used here which would extend the avenues for activities.

Awesome idea, especially for primary school
Very inspiring!

http://designthatmatters.org/portfolio/projects/kinkajou/

comments.text: Let's then look for ways for making these technologies more available. I agree with Meena, the target in these case is to look for (responsible) sponsors.

Jenny, 
This is a great idea that could play a role to disseminate learning. Part of what is still a bit unclear to me is that this challenge seems to assume that the "tools and services for students" already exist, and the focus is rather on ways to "increase the availability".
If you think of it this way, your Inspiration is not so much the Portable Library (it already exists), but ways in which this system can be made affordable and put everywhere.
As a side note, this system is used by Dr. Paul Polak to promote the use of trutle pumps and inexpensive irrigation systems ($1 USD or less) in Bangladesh, India and across Asia. Dr. Polak uses it in conjunction with a traveling theater.

Fab that this builds upon the optics used on the View Masters that we used to play with when we were kids (or is that showing my age?!) Smart thinking to use this feature to convince Fisher Price to contribute financial support for the project. What other kinds of mash-ups can meet challenges in providing learning tools? Do any of these point to funding opportunities?

comments.text: Great idea about boiling down language labs to their essence. 2 thoughts on lowering cost: 1) basic recording/playback devices (the ones used on audio greeting cards & keychain voice recorders) are available for less than $5 (even less for lower memory and if bought in bulk), 2) many simple cellphones (cellphones have almost 50% penetration in India) include recording/playback functionality.

Great idea about boiling down language labs to their essence: hearing your own pronunciation. 2 thoughts on lowering cost: 1) basic recording/playback devices (the ones used on audio greeting cards & keychain voice recorders) are available for

Maybe this could be combined with the Ring+Sing concept, with prerecorded songs to emulate...

tv_and_sms_201d_classroom_201d_setting.description: The ideal face-to-face classroom situation is when each student follows the thread of the lecture and can answer the interactive questions posed by the lecturer/trainer/teacher. Implementing this ideal in a distance education context using existing contemporary methods such as the Internet might be expensive for a developing country.
tv_and_sms_201d_classroom_201d_setting.creator: 28890c0b3a775ebd22755c0a1a35b9f4

comments.text:
I love this idea! 
In 2007, i tried a similar idea when I taught in Indonesia since practically all of my students owned a cell phone (i.e. for for their assignment, having them text me a use of a taught Grammar pattern when encountered out of school). But due to the lack of a centralized, organized system, it was difficult for me to efficiently keep track and assess the responses as well as provide feedback for my 30+ students. 
I think with the advent of real-time text-based survey technologies, this concept is definitely feasible with multiple-choice questions. The main things I'm curious about revolve around how the progress reports will organized and how they will be delivered to the teacher (text/mail/internet).

10 - 15 mobiles could be kept with the teacher and are distributed when ever the class starts and as the class gets over the phones are returned back to the teacher for the next session , in this way not many phones will need to be purchased

Interesting way of combining the interactivity of mobiles with the scale of television, especially when the teacher is unavailable or does not have the requisite knowledge/experience in a particular area.
Looks like sending a text message in India currently costs ~1-3 cents per message, or ~1 cent for every 10 messages at the company bulk rate (some companies have also offered free text messaging to promote various services). Receiving a text message is free. Assuming you can get the bulk rate, cost is within reason: the direct text messaging fees to provide 1 student with say a year of weekly 1 hour programs, w/ 20 messages per program (10 messages sent by the student, 10 responses sent back to the student; interaction every 6 minutes), is ~$1 at the bulk rate.
Costs could be further lowered if 1) a carrier could be convinced to subsidize the educational text messages as a social campaign, 2) simple text-based mobile phones were acquired through donations.

tv_and_sms_201d_classroom_201d_setting.title: TV and sms ”classroom” setting

mobile_phone_learning.description: Mobile phones, compared to computers, are low cost & have high penetration in developing countries (in Africa, penetration is ~50% for mobiles vs. ~10% for internet).  So, there’s a large opportunity to deliver appropriate educational technology/content through mobiles, for those who currently can't access low-cost computer initiatives like One Laptop Per Child. Mobiles, computers, & other technologies can improve developing world education in parallel, and may possibly converge in the future. Please watch the video to see what a difference m-learning could make.

ring_sing_mobile_karaoke_for_english_lan.description: Music can be a powerful and tool in helping language learners practice saying letters and words. The Ring + Sing system would deliver curated karaoke content to educators via ringtone and SMS for children to sing and practice their English pronunciation together in the classroom.

comments.text: I like it!I am looking into the feasibility of teaching conversational English for free in rural areas. This idea is a flag in the right direction!

We've been doing this for years on EFL Classroom 2.0, (hit Teach - Karaoke on http://eflclassroom.com ). Thousands of files/songs we make using karafun player. Now we need to get it mobile or able to embed at least. but great idea and I'd have no problem helping out...
I like your thinking
This sounds awesome.  I can say from personal experience trying to sing along to songs helped me learn more Spanish.  There should be a way to make the song downloads free and legal somehow.
@Vincent Thanks! When I taught English in Vietnam, it was astounding how many students knew words to American & British songs (esp power ballads :)

Wow, great idea Ann! Love the creative utilization of mobile phones, but even more excited by the use of singing, which makes the practice repetition fun. In fact, I actually have a friend that improved her reading/speaking of a new language through karaoke.

@Sandy Thanks, second to a mobile phone, I think a computer would be my second choice delivery platform. Even a simple DVD + TV would work, the key would be prepping the teacher on how to teach without having mastered English themselves.

I really like the idea of karaoke as a way to  learn english. I could also see this as a stand-alone (non-mobile based) product.... like a Karaoke Machine, or even software for a computer. Mobile seems the most instantly-accessible though.

comments.text:
Michael, 
This is an interesting video. But the central question of the challenge is "how to increase the availability" of learning tools and services.
The focus is not on creating new tools and services, but to make for their widespread adoption. I understand it as the mechanisms like Creative Commons and Open Source licensing which break down the barriers to access. 
In a larger view, it is also about the logistics of how to transport efficiently products that generate educational services where these learning tools happen to be.  So, in this case, it is not about creating a new classroom, but -as I understand- the mechanisms under which existing/ readily adaptable products and services can be made available.
Thanks for sharing anyways!

I love this idea! What a great learning tool in a low-resource environment; they're cheap to produce and they open up a world of creativity and imagination. The cards are beautifully designed and the games look like they'd be really fun - I want to play!

I was encouraged to find that this is hopefully going to be a $100 reality, pioneered by the "One Laptop Per Child" folks. Check it out here:http://mashable.com/2010/05/27/olpc-xo-3/Complete with Android! :)

I am probably a litte late on this but to my knowledge, the Indian company HCL wants to build an Ipad for $35 supported by the Indian state. If learning material was free, it would be a good start for most classes.

Vincent, Thank you for your feedback ! Yes I do agree that right now it doesn't seem like a very low-cost option. But with the Android OS being open source and freely available, I think it is an extremely viable option in the near future. Especially combined with the fact that the mobile educational app market for smartphones is growing  by leaps, with some really good applications which kids should have access to, not to mention the exposure to the technology itself.

Amrita, like the idea of a "loaner library" to spread out the costs over multiple users. I do have concerns about the cost of Android smartphones (as opposed to more basic, lower-cost phones) currently, but could see this becoming increasingly viable in the future.

comments.text: I like the idea of helping communities help themselves instead of getting support from outside. Now how do you create this fund and who would manage it?

Hi Mayowa,
Good point about trying to get local entrepreneurs involved in supporting education. Already existing businesses, both local and MNCs could also presumably sponsor schools (especially ones that provide products/services for parents & children). For example, in the US, you often have local businesses sponsoring children's sports team like Little League, and buying congratulatory ads in school yearbooks.

Thanks Meena. Checked out Vincent's submission. Fantastic idea, and I'm about to build on it.
This idea's a little bit different though. Imagine going into a community and starting something as simple as a small scale viewing center (for cricket matches, soccer, movies, etc). 
A team of small business experts goes into a community, identifies opportunities and then selects people to introduce and manage businesses (entrepreneurs selected based on local reputation, business acumen, etc).
In return the entrepreneurs agree to pay a certain percentage of profits to one or two schools (to help with growth and development). Some of the money can also be used for scholarships from really poor families. So the money goes into a pool, and the schools decide how best to use it.
Hi Mayowa  good to see the work being done at Fate Foundation. You might find Vincent's example from a while back interesting as well if you didn't see it already: http://bit.ly/aGKpQ3

shared_chalkboard_posters.description:
Kids love picture books because images bring life to humdrum black and white text. On top of that, images are helpful as learning tools because they are much easier to remember than words. However, many children lack visual stimulation because their schools do not have textbooks or classroom posters. 

The solution? PosterShare!
PosterShare rotates educational posters among schools. The posters are stuck on chalkboards with magnets and serve as temporary classroom posters - imagine different sets to learn fractions, shapes, human anatomy, etc. Since the posters are posted on chalkboards, students can draw and write around them in a non-permanent way. Teachers can switch posters as they move through the curriculum.
shared_chalkboard_posters.creator: 5556a57b48e6af8a0654c9c668ec566b

comments.text:
This solution is great because it addresses the way we learn and retain information. Children learn differently and visualization is key. One of the greatest strengths of this proposal is that its very economical and practical.  I think having the posters up on the chalk board with magnets and a sharing system, like the one you proposed, is a great solution that would take little individual effort on that of the teacher/school but have a large potential impact on the learning of students. 
I agree that since some chalkboard's, especially older ones, aren't magnetic, there needs to be another way to attach these posters. Velcro is a good possible solution, but maybe it should be less permanentlike that blue putty as temporary adhesive? 
I also like the idea of central mailing, "like Netflix" that Vincent proposed. I think that would make the system easier for everyone. Although, like others, I'm not sure of the logistics and how that would work cost-wise, but I think its something worth looking into.

@Sandy: how about MadLib-style posters? Teachers could randomly put different sentence-starters on the board and children would fill in the text in-between, creating their own stories!@Ember: Velcro is an interesting idea - also much hardier than magnets! My understanding is that chalkboards can be made magnetic with magnetic paint (akin to chalkboard paint). I like magnets because they provide flexibility and let kids draw/write right around the posters, which I think gives them more ownership of the material. Velcro magnets? :)

One small thing--the chalkboards here aren't always magnetic, so I propose sticking velcro to the back of each poster and then to the walls.  that way, chalk board space isn't taken up and the posters are still interchangable.

A quick brainstorm of ways an entrepreneur could charge schools for this service:- subscription fee- pay-per-use- charge advertisers but provide posters for free, like websites. Ads could be on the entrepreneur's vehicle, or simply other posters that get put up in classrooms.  
Of course, the last point is problematic because you give some organization direct access to impressionable children (and risk propagating consumer culture), but maybe we could find more benign "advertisers"? Take development organizations, for instance. Some economists have found that simply telling children about the returns to education is an incredibly cost effective way to keep them in school. They could use the PosterShare entrepreneur to spread socially-beneficial information and do so credibly if the entrepreneur is connected to the organization!
I like where smriti is pushing this... how can this be built into an entrepreneurial model. what are the ways that locals might be employed to create or distribute these?

This is really cool. It makes me think that they could be like poster-sized worksheets. ... many posters in schools already give students the answers, and yet some of the most powerful learning happens when kids create it themselves. i like the idea of combining the chalkboard with a poster... what's the prompt on a poster to help a kid create a thought?! Great idea!

its like instead of providing book to every kid , we are reducing the amount of stationary which needs to be transported to the rural sector at the same time making the activity more interactive and encouraging collaborative learning 
personally do not think mail pricing would be an issue but with reliability the goods with robust exteriors/approach do best in rural setting that needs to be kept in mind while developing the concept (like meena had mentioned maybe painted murals which can not be vandalized), i was also wondering as to what incentive could be given to the entrepreneur to provide this service ?

Interesting idea, especially since posters are relatively low cost & light to transport. Perhaps posters could even be mailed to & from a central distribution point, ala Netflix? Anyone know whether this makes sense in terms of mail pricing/reliability in India?

shared_chalkboard_posters.title: Shared chalkboard posters

comments.text: Great stuff Kate! I think you should post your Portable Desk concept as it's own post with images so that it may inspire others to cross-pollinate it with other ideas.

My research project looked at how to distribute cultural probes to a rural community to inquire about their needs/aspirations. While not a business model originally, this got me to thinking about how their could be an educational entrepreneur who made toolkits for schools (see my very rough concept here: http://cargocollective.com/karapecknold/#27050/FIELD-DESK). When I first made these I ensured that all the items could be sourced inside or near to the country I was going to work in (Rwanda). Later, I took my original idea and created a craft kit for a young child: http://www.flickr.com/photos/olivelife/3820755445/
An education toolkit/field bag that is created, built and delivered in India?

Hi there, I just came across this post - I'm Giles, Founder/Director of Proboscis and the designer/creator of the StoryCubes. They are part of a tool set we have developed over the past 10 years for communicating ideas in simple ways - Diffusion Shareables. We have also designed a simple downloadable hybrid digital/paper book format (Diffusion eBooks) and created http://bookleteer.com - a free web app for people to design and create their own eBooks and StoryCubes.
We have used both eBooks & StoryCubes extensively in schools projects ourselves (we are starting a new long term project using them in a primary school in London this September). We also co-designed and supported a workshop in a secondary school in Delhi in 2009 which used both eBooks and StoryCubes very effectively - http://diffusion.org.uk/?p=1668.
bookleteer has been created to support eBooks/StoryCubes being created in around 80 different languages, including Hindi, Marathi, Tamil & Bengali. Whilst we aren't yet able to support Urdu script, the language can be presented via our support for Arabic (with native Right-to-left reading of eBooks generated). All these tools have been designed to be simple and cheap to make, using basic technologies and building upon craft skills. As publication formats they also allow for sharing to take place not just digitally but physically too. bookleteer now has a low-cost short run printing service (PPOD) for professionally printed & bound versions of eBooks & StoryCubes - here's a post about a project we did last year using eBooks to record stories about objects in the British Museum's collections from 2 villagers from Papua New Guinea's Reite Coast (free to downloaded from http://diffusion.org.uk); which we have also printed PPOD copies of that anthropologist took back to share with the other villagers last month (July):http://bookleteer.com/blog/2010/06/printed-ethnographic-notebooks/
The design schematics for the eBooks are licensed under Creative Commons, whilst the designs of the StoryCube boxes remain our copyright as we currently manufacture and sell packs of the 'blank' StoryCubes as products. However, we're open to suggestion for other ways to use them to support learning around the world.

These are great thoughts and inspiration for learning tools. Thanks! Curious what you guys think about models for engagement/distribution and how local entrepreneurs might be inspired to provide these to/for schools! Open source/free tools are great, but often don't get to these schools. Any inspirational references for business ideas?
Yes! And I also think it could relate to ways library books get shared/delivered/translated as per this idea: http://gu.nu/pR
Perhaps these could also work well as part of Jane's suggestion here: http://bit.ly/cV9rXY

I like the work I have seen from Probiscus. The open source model is very powerful as a model for connecting people - especially when access is itself the biggest challenge. In this example what I admire is the recognition of storytelling as a tool for learning. The implications for development of creative skillsets (what we certainly need) is clear. Thumbs up from me :)

There are aspects that are free to download (scroll to the bottom of the site for resources). But I'm guessing at this point we're okay to at least provide a bit of inspiration to the challenge before concepts get developed.

Kara, 
Are these open source? I think its important for this challenge to have the most cost-effective solutions and for widespread availability, open source tools could be key.
double-applause!

For families without electricity, solar lanterns (like the Kiran lanterns by D.Light!) provide a safer, brighter and ultimately cheaper alternative to kerosene lamps. They cost $10 a pop and can pay themselves off in as little as six months in savings on kerosene. But what if families don't have $10, or access to microloans?

comments.text: Jennifer, I like how your concept makes access to a formal financial institution less relevant and instead relies on the informal financing mechanisms that are strong in many communities, like ROSCAs. One thing I'd want to think about is whether the social pressure to get households to contribute their share after getting the lights is a sufficient incentive? One reason ROSCAs and MFIs work is the carrot of future pay-outs or loans - can we make this an indefinite game of sorts, where there's the potential for group savings for other products in the future, and hence a financial reason to maintain your credibility?Great to have more people thinking about consumer financing for productive investments like solar lights![Note: I worked at d.light before, so am not an entirely neutral third party!]

Well thought out community financing model! Social ties encourage cooperation & discourage gaming of the system. Any thoughts on how the money would be collected & disbursed (joint bank account, trusted community member)?

Hi Jennifer,This is a very similar concept you might check out.
http://openideo.com/open/how-might-we-increase-the-availability-of-affordable-learning-tools-educational-for-children-in-the-developing-world/concepting/solarlight-kits-lighting-classrooms-and-empowering-students/

Great!My thoughts: would every child need to have their own lamp or could they join together in small study groups for the dark part of the evening?Your calculations could be cut in half, at least!
Or perhaps change the old way the schoolday is traditionally planned, so that they could use a larger part of the daylight?

roaming_books_and_tools.description: An entrepreneur could start a business delivering books, low-cost computers with educational programs, board games, playground equipment, and other tools or supplies to affordable private schools in a given area. The schools could rent the tools and equipment for a given period of time.

comments.text: Great Idea! This has the possibility to really take off through the involvement of vendors and traders to make their collections more interesting.

I really love this idea.  It feels like "social media on wheels".  Nomadic.  Entertaining.  Lively.  Not only is it extremely efficient, but it's uplifting and playful in its delivery method.  Children have short attention spans and an insatiable curiosity.  The notion of a "knowledge cart" or "idea cart" that delivers new materials every week (or even day) is exciting... I wish one would roll down my street every day!  It's like Twitter, but with touch.  ,)  
I could see this expanding in many ways, incorporating a number of other concepts I've seen shared during this challenge.  Companies, organizations or even individuals could sponsor a cart for a day or week, curating a collection of materials that teaches an entire lesson plan.. with new materials and projects arriving each day... I imagine the cart rolling up, bells jingling to signal it's arrival, colorful puppets strung up top, their legs dancing about, ready for an afternoon performance that introduces the week's lesson.   The cart might appear with new surprises every day... books, art materials, interesting new foods, music.  Eventually, Sagmeister riding up top.  ,)  Maybe a merry band of grandmums arrive to tell stories for the day.
This has the potential to build an entirely new eco-system around it, involving local (and even international) businesses, artisans & families and fundamentally changing the structure of education to connect an entire community to its children, which I think is wonderful.

Most school books are like automobiles = they are parked more than 90% of their life time. Books and other school equipment is in shelves or storage most of the time.To Share Books between schools much like a time-share-vacation-home would be great!!!I mean a smart schedule could be designed, to circulate them around the district, for example mathematics for beginners are in week 1-5 in school A, and then these books are transported to school B from week 6-10. other books is circulated in opposite direction.
Also : schedule the school day and use the premises in a smarter way, a normal class room are only used by one group of kids for 7-8 hours. Classes could be in smaller groups if the day is divided.
(i just posted similar time-share-comments in other threads regarding computers and reading-lights)
Excellent concept - Just imagine what will happen when the vendors compete with each other to "spice up" their offerings!

I love this idea! By having schools rent books, play equipment and board games for a short period of time, schools face lower investment costs (at least in the short run). Also, children will be more excited to have access to these educational materials knowing that they won't be in their schools forever.
My question is this: how could this entrepreneur continue earning income when schools are not in session?

I can totally imagine something like this working! And a great way for schools to get exposed to an updated range of progressive educational tools out there.

comments.text: I like how this could be the primary mechanism by which so many of the other great concepts can be delivered! Quite literally, a vehicle for change!
I love this concept. I would look for the sponsorization of The Jim Henson Company.

This is a great concept Meena. I've heard of many similar theater programs used to teach lessons about healhcare, social issues, moral lessons etc. I really like the idea of using puppets to make it more kid friendly too.
Great way to entertain, engage, and educate!

I love that this idea turns us back towards something that is so simple and visual and tangible in storytelling.  And I really like the spirit of "making" this inspires around educating our children.  :)  I remember watching puppet shows when I was young... fascinated by every detail about the puppets themselves.  It taught me that making things that "tell stories" can satisfy & entertain others, and allow me to safely express my feelings & share my ideas without having to speak them aloud.  (Aren't our avitars our "puppets" and our social media entries our performances?  Come to think of it, my iPhone is a great "personal puppet".)  
Sharing is so essential to building global connection & community... I can imagine these beautiful, unique puppets/performances created by local artisans eventually shared between towns/cities/countries to share modern day stories, borrowing on the Chinese puppet theater tours.  Puppets from Detroit touring Mumbai, puppets from Kibera in the schools of Paris, etc.
I also think we should seek to solve any issue with ideas that are inherently beautiful and this one really is.

Don't pay much attention to my quick scribble of the puppet van! The concept is more about the entire platform than the vehicle itself. I expect that the actual design of the vans could happen in collaboration with some of the many grassroots innovators in India who create mobile enterprises: http://bit.ly/cd6PeZ

comments.text: Hi Sally! Did you know your Inspiration has the most applauds? Congrats!
I really like your idea: Work for studying

I really like the relevance of this idea. Meena's idea of adding design thinking as a topic to address local challenges. I also think that such crafts could be related to their environment and context.
I also think that there could be a focus on relevant social topics like health, community and poverty. And teaching these young children design thinking could inspire them to come up with ideas to help their community.

Nice, as it reflects the realities in a lot of countries... young people sadly can't afford the luxury of devoting full time to education. The next question is how we help create the level of income needed to allow them to focus more on school

Hi Sally... I'm also thinking there could be opps. to add Design Thinking as a topic to address local challenges with the craft skills they are learning. The Barefoot College in rural India encourage this kind of trans-disciplinary thinking to address socio-economic issues: http://bit.ly/dxt4nf They don't call it Design Thinking but it's of that ilk. Akin to what Emily Pilloton's up to at the moment with in North Carolina.

Yes, this concept is really wise. Beyond academic CV, it gives children with enhanced technical skills the opportunity to develop them and making profit, projecting them into their local future. We should then answer the question "How might we increase the availability of this initiatives in the developing world? My applause.

I agree this is a really compelling inspiration, especially since these schools are entrepreneurial ventures themselves. Some questions this raises for me is how might we turn some of the areas of content focus for these schools (math, English language learning, test prep) into business opportunities? And how might we inspire entrepreneurs to work with schools and students? Essentially, how can we turn this idea of entrepreneurial learning into a service offered to schools? If you have any ideas for provocative companies or organizations that do something like this (in schools or in a totally different sector), i'd love to see it!
I think its a very practical solution for the developing world. Can the students make money from the academic subject as well or is it restricted to the crafts subjects?
Hi Shazz Mack... I notice there's some more info about the comprehensive collaborations between Sally & co + CMES here: http://www.designthatmatters.org/news/dtm-blog/project/cmes/

My university (Georgia Tech) was started with a similar concept. The students back in the 19th century would spend the morning learning and the afternoon working in the shop to make money [and apply what they learned]
I like the blend of academics, vocational skills, and entrepreneurship. Where's the best place to learn more about this model and see if they've exported to concept to any other countries? Thanks.

the_clean_water_trucker.description: Dirty water kills 5,000 children a day! This is crazy. The concept "the Clean Water Trucker" is a water purification system that adapts to the child's lifestyle, school schedule, and creates the potential to learn about dirty water and the solution.
the_clean_water_trucker.creator: 7d77e825b80cff62a72e680c1c81424f

comments.text:
Thanks for the comments! My initial inspiration came from the documentary "Flow," which opened my eyes to the crazy problems we are having today and the problems we will face in the near future. Plus, children and the elderly are the main victims in this war for clean water. What is even more crazy, there is not a single clean water product / system that comes to mind focusing the needs and lifestyle of the children. We need more solutions that revolve around them to be easily adaptable. 
The whole trucker idea came from a few photos of these children in the city Khartoum, Sudan. The photo showed them with their toy trucks, which they built by hand. Ingenious! They would take wood scraps and garbage to create a toy truck they would 'drive' everywhere, even to school. Check it out at: 'http://www.kk.org/streetuse/archives/2006/08/more_african_truck_toys.php"
Nice rendering Faris! Vincent  I've got one coming up but will wait till there's a few more concepts up on the board.
Good insight about how schools can be used as a distribution point for addressing community issues, while also facilitating learning. What other issues could benefit from this approach?

Good idea to approach this problem with a playful solution. I agree kids should learn about their environment its dangers and how to handle it. Although i like your idea, i would suggest to rethink the transportation a little. Maybe use a device/object/system which is easier to use in a all-day situation? Like having bigger wheels or so? I definitly think there is potential in the concept!

the_clean_water_trucker.title: The Clean Water Trucker

comments.text: This is really interesting!  In Mexico the postal service often does not get to remote rural communities, however the Coca-Cola truck does distribute to the only small little shop in these communities.  The first think that comes to my mind is that they could serve as the educational material distributers, after all they will go to the little shop to sell, why not to deliver the educational material as well.

Part of my reasoning behind the example below is that, while I find Cola Life admirable  it's been a while now of trying with Coke and it seems that the activism has overun the desire to actually create change on the ground  which could be achieved by exploring alternative distribution networks and partners that are more aligned to social enterprise.

Pablo -  Even though technology is fantastic, it is not always the only way to go. There is (I think) a danger in just presuming that a tech solution is the right way to go before investigating it. Another important question to ask, for example is: What type of technology will these people deal with after they leave education, and in what way will they interact with it.

About your link. On the right way, I think i imagined something that was more merged into the local society. More like a treasure hunt game maybe? In any case something bigger. That would give the kids a direct answer to the often raised question: why are we learning this?

Pablo  as long as you are prepared to factor in maintenance  this has been the downfall of many development 'solutions' involving technology. There's also the case of digital literacy and resistance to external endeavors which provide barriers. I'm not saying it can't be done  just that there may be massive hurdles. 
Daniel  good post! How's this for an example? http://bit.ly/cOKrl6

i understand what you are saying but i really think technology would be the cheapest solution in the long term, it is true when you say that the required equipment is not available everywhere yet, therefore the real question here would be , how can we make this technologies available for them at the lowest price, or how can we raise the money that is needed for a project this size? instead of discarding technology and going back to the stone age teaching techniques we should be asking ourselves how to make it available to them don't you think? cheers

comments.text:
I think this idea came originally from the Teach for America programme in the US.   In the developing world, its a particularly good idea because of the incredible shortage of qualified teachers.    All the money in the world cannot provide education if you don't have teachers - how do you get around that problem - presumably either by using professionals / recent graduates as with this programme or by technologies which can replace some of the work of teachers or support less qualified teachers.
I think it's also important to distinguish between the levels of education.  Teaching primary and basic literacy / numeracy is very different from teaching high school and problem solving.    The two very different problems are likely to need different solutions.

Very interesting. Madhavi, do you know how the 15K INR/month Teach For India fellowship stipends support are funded? Are the schools providing any of it? Just wondering what the direct cost is to a school compared to the ~2.4K INR average Affordable Private School teacher salary in Hyderabad.

mid_day_meals_enhance_enrollment_and_att.description: The Mid-day Meal Scheme is the popular name for school meal programme in India. The key objectives of the programme are: protecting children from classroom hunger, increasing school enrolment and attendance, improved socialisation among children belonging to all castes, addressing malnutrition, and social empowerment through provision of employment to women.

I was reading about the Timaktu Collective in Andhra Pradesh in the weekend that also provides school lunches but produces some of the food for them out of community gardens which are tended by students  providing a further avenue for education. http://bit.ly/d6b4qS This would be difficult for urban schools but could be a great idea for rural schools alongside the provision of meals.
