harness_the_power_of_educators_worldwide.description: If crowd sourcing can be used to build a massive Wikipedia, solve math problems, write code for a free operating system, search for extraterrestrial life, etc., why not use it to build an educational system from the ground up?
harness_the_power_of_educators_worldwide.creator: 7c8e822d3f154bb2b046f6e1085eea54

comments.text:
I had a very similiar idea on this several years ago. I would love to see this carried out. 
There is several groups doing this for higher edcation: www.openstudy.com www.ocwconsortium.comwww.ocw.mit.edu

Ashley thanks for the comment!  I agree that tapping the resource of experienced teachers would be a great way to build an effective educational curriculum.  I bet it would even be self-editing in terms of those that get involved.  The teachers who have lost faith in education, been burnt out, grown cynical, tired or whatever will most likely not be interested in contributing to the building of 'Open Source School' materials.  So it will probably be the teachers that are the most passionate about education and that care about students in developing countries as well as theirs that will be inspired and motivated to work together and contribute.  A system that builds on passion and excitement without the worry of being stalled by pessimists.  Thanks again!

This is a fantastic idea, when it comes to education and improving a standardized system, I think is the best way to improve education is to utilize the experience and understanding of teachers who have spent their lives "learning" how students learnthey are the experts! I agree that this could be hugely beneficial to improving the quality and diversity of education developing world.
Thanks Helen!  Agreed!  I can't help but think that a lot of educators would be excited to contribute and that it could be a great resource for struggling developing world educations systems.

Paul, Thanks for the comment!  Sorry I missed your concept. I will definitely take a look at it. If this concept goes forward there is a lot of potential for contribution and development.  Thanks again for the reference!
This idea sounds amazing!It could be beneficial for so many people.:)

Hey guys, I posted a similar concept "Moodle to the Power of Mooch". The Moodle Open Source Learning Management System with the MOOCH open community Hub allows anyone using Moodle (about 40,000 schools & universities around the world at the moment) to share any lessons they create with anyone else. I reckon this could provide the platform you are after. I'd be happy to set up and run a prototype system to see if it's what you were thinking about.See www.learningwall.org/demo for a business style demo.

Thanks for the comment Simon!  Great ideas!  I totally agree that the program could be expanded to encompass higher education, supplemental education, trades, etc.  I think you are right in that, like Wikipedia, it would require some sort of permanent IT staff support but, yes, easily covered by advertising or government subsidies, donations, etc.  Your student question forums are a great idea!  Not only would the students benefit from receiving answers to their study questions but I bet the education contributors would also.  My mother is an elementary school teacher and I bet she would love to develop relationships with young students on the other side of the world by trading a couple emails every evening or so.  It could not only give her a sense of pleasure in being able to help but it might also enrich the lessons that she teaches to her regular students during the day.  Some great possibilities that could be developed here.  Thanks again!

Girish, Thanks for the comment!  I agree that the convincing is key. But I also think that once educators understand that the 'Open Source School' project is a platform on which they can contribute their talents, expertise and passion for teaching to a greater good that is much bigger than themselves, they will be inspired to contribute their time and efforts.  Also, it could be seen by teachers on a tight budget as a way to help less advantaged students in developing countries without having to write a check.  Whatever the motivation, the incremental aspect of the platform would allow educators to contribute as little or as much as they have time for.  An easy way to contribute no matter what the situation.  Thanks again for the comment!

I really like this idea. I believe it could be expanded to offer education courses at higher levels. It would require some permenant staff to direct/moderate and to handle IT and admin etc but this could easily be covered by some limited advertising on the site. 
As well as fixed content this could also provide forums or something similar for students to ask question and recieve answeres from contributors.

As long as we can convince teachers to work "pro bono" or non-gratis, this is going to be huge. As the poster asks, if Wikipedia is possible, why not this? Indeed, why not?! I wait to watch its execution into something real and would love to contribute time to teaching / uploading materials.

harness_the_power_of_educators_worldwide.title: Harness the Power of Educators Worldwide!

shared_resources_and_experiences_.description: The idea of shared resources and experiences stems from the thought that education is not just about literacy or academic learning but also about developing critical thinking, behavioral, interactive skills and instilling a sense of belonging to the community. The children studying in the affordable private schools have limited or no access to the activities which engage in developing these skills. They also have very limited interaction with their more privileged counterparts. To bring about this interaction and to ensure that the APS children have access to resources other than academic learning, the project “SHARED RESOURCES and EXPERIENCES” is proposed.
shared_resources_and_experiences_.creator: 8afcf6a9916a4ea9341e48cab658e671

distribution_network_of_expats_and_busin.description:
Develop an infrastructure that moves school supply donations into India via travelers visiting the country. Many visitors do not use their entire luggage allotment, or they have extra space in their luggage that could be used to transport donations cheaply into India. These donations could be dropped of at an airport kiosk that collects the donations from abroad and distributes them to local schools.

This is a very incremental approach, however low-cost distribution is a big concern and my guess is that  lots of ex-pats and business people would like to give back to India. This can be a very easy way for first-world travelers to participate.
distribution_network_of_expats_and_busin.creator: e570d4eb8d96d6a184300eb08e1c9e42

blackboards_whiteboards_tools_for_making.description:
We think of blackboards as something common to a lot of classrooms, but this isn't always the case.  I think they are cool because they make information, discussions, knowledge, and feedback visible among a group when used as a place to document.  The often are reusable - i.e. they can be erased and drawn on again - and they support collaboration.

Are there other analog platforms that accomplish these same tasks?
blackboards_whiteboards_tools_for_making.creator: b4290822e3324003a9b6c7212ac4af8f

comments.text:
Thanks Erik! You are right...mobility is very important...not only in space but in time too.  One of the challenges is access to land and the buildings to support learning infrastructures.  It just costs way too much  even for relatively wealthy institutions.  
One solution which the Society for the Elimination of Rural Poverty (http://www.serp.ap.gov.in/CMSA/) has been undertaking is to use jeeps fitted with demonstration tools to visit villages - along with someone to explain the costs, risks, & benefits of organic and new farming practices.  It helps because travel isn't always possible for field workers who spend most of their time working or tending to household tasks.  It also means that meaningful practices are stabilized so they can be communicated with some fidelity across many farming villages.

Blackboards and whiteboards are extremely powerful tools, whether you are a designer or a student in a developing country.
There seems to be much discussion about mobility, and portability of the classroom as well. Would it be possible to provide a mobile toolkit that made teaching, learning, and collaboration available virtually anywhere, with no need for a classroom?
A backpack that contained pens and folded out into a whiteboard? An affordable computer teaching interface that integrated traditional teaching methods with modern technology? To play off the idea of shipping containers... could they be equipped with these necessary toolkits, deployed, and set up as a community teaching ventures? Less effort required to start up could create an easier experience for others. We streamline the process and make it as easy as possible for less fortunate countries to learn.
Some earlier suggestions: http://bit.ly/cnuy8n + http://bit.ly/9GBoWJLooking forward to hearing of further directions.

blackboards_whiteboards_tools_for_making.title: Blackboards & Whiteboards: Tools for Making Visible

comments.text: I think any kind of gaming can work  doesn't need to be computer driven gaming. Have posted an example here which still meets the list of provisions above: http://bit.ly/cOKrl6

I agree, as a mother of a 6yr old, gaming has its unique way of capturing the interest of kids, rewarding learning and sending subliminal messages. Building on the question of who would build these games, it's also important to ask how these kids would access these games. Most students do not have internet access, however most poor families do have cell phones...

Right on! Growing up, a lot of my vocabulary and verbal skills were developed by playing RPGs. This also reminds me a bit of the sci-fi classic Ender's Game, for what it's worth.
A great RPG could teach math/resource management skills (making sure your inventory is properly stocked, stat min/maxing), expand vocabularies through dialogue and skill names, and encourage creativity and logic skills through puzzles (think Zelda). If employed in an educational way, games could be very, very powerful. 
The question is: who's going to develop these games? And on what platform are they going to exist? I know kongregate (look it up) is a cool social online gaming network - maybe a similar structure would be good for educational gaming.

infinity_paper_affordable_durable_and_re.description: Paper is a resource that every student needs. By providing a durable, reusable and affordable paper, students and teachers will never have to be without.
infinity_paper_affordable_durable_and_re.creator: 6e962aea25038c9fbeb8ff102cc56843

comments.text:
Thanks for the comment, Vincent. I do not know of any companies selling styrene paper in this format, but "styrene paper" does exist, but it's a thin styrene foam used in packaging. 
I am working by memory from my first hand experiences with this material. Different densities are available, I believe, and its possible that testing will lead to a more specific material selection.

Great concept, which could potentially lower paper costs & environmental impact in education, and perhaps other sectors as well. Not familiar with polystyrene myself, so would be interested to hear about other's experiences (ease of use, durability, etc.) with writing and erasing on it? Also, are there any organizations out there already producing polystyrene sheets that could be used for this purpose?

... I suppose what is also easier it to assume that sheets can be reused locally. Someone suggested making dinosaurs and other toys out of cardboard. These sheets can also be used in crafts such as dioramas, masks, or as inserts to stiffen fabric crafts. They can also be used as dividers in filing, or to make signage ... I'm brainstorming here. :) That actually seems way more economical than trying to recycle them. (These sheets are easy to cut with scissors, sew with thread and keep folds well.)

Hi Nathan - It's possible that the sheets will have to be shipped to recycling plants outside of the country they're being used in, though recycling facilities do exist. 
The material I'm imagining is the sheet material common in hobby building and design modeling. My impression is that this type takes to recycling better than other forms such as Styrofoam, though I will do some more research this weekend and share what I find. 
Are there any materials experts out there?

Good idea! That said, I have a lot of concerns about disposal of these sheets once they simply cannot be used. Polystyrene is very difficult to dispose of in an eco-friendly manner, so how would we get around that?

Further on business sustainability, it would be great to develop the ability to make the pages in small batches locally. We probably already have this ability for the custom printing part, but if a local shop in some town could buy, finance or have donated one small machine that would allow it to supply schools in the surroonding towns, that could be sustainable long term.

In terms of business sustainability - A business can sell sheets, optionally pre-printed with lines or grids. The business can also buy back the used sheets if they become damaged for recycling into new "paper". 
I think the greatest limitation will be on material costs. Partnerships withmanufacturers looking for charitable donations would be ideal.

This is pretty cool Dawn! Paper is spectacularly wasteful and any substitute would be ideal for developing countries.
It would also be quite a cost-mitigating product for municipalities and corporations.
Awesome, I think sustainable, affordable and semi-permanent writing tools are a must for this project. A similar idea I submitted: http://bit.ly/acCpA1

@Mark, Yes, of course! Worksheets can be created with marker or pen by the teacher/school specifically relating to what they are teaching, and reused at length by the students. (eg. lines for handwriting, grids for graphing, etc)

@Mark, Yes, of course! Worksheets can be created with marker or pen by the teacher/school specifically relating to what they are teaching, and reused at length by the students. (eg. lines for handwriting, grids for graphing, etc)
Great idea! Could information be printed on the sheets? The sheets could be incorporated into language/math workbooks and thus allow the books to be reused.

need_based_bridges_for_schools_.description: Adopt a school allows users like you and me to log into social networks where we can view a local map of schools, non-profits and donors in a community, village or a city. We can then look at needs that a school may have which could range from getting additional tutors, to setting up an after school program, to find a way to pay their electricity bills, to health insurance for kids, food programs and so on. Our goals are then to bridge these gaps by helping the schools connect with one or more NGO's or donors. And once we are successful in bridging them, sustaining those bridges. This might mean calling them, or writing a letter or visiting if you are in the same are. But basically as users helping the school bridge these needs gaps by building a local network of community members and organizations to build up the school, and try to make it more sustainable.
need_based_bridges_for_schools_.creator: 45dfa3ce3534aaba390cc7d10af86e26

comments.text: This has huge potential, but my interpretation of the costs is a bit different. I'm wondering how the information about the needs of schools is collected and communicated to the organizers.

transform_backpackers_into_teachers.description: How can we harness the power, enthusiasm and creativity of young travelers who would be willing to involve themselves as volunteers in local education?
transform_backpackers_into_teachers.creator: 84c04044b0796f3cedaff79875d9bbd5

comments.text: I did an ethnography project with schools for migrant worker children in Beijing.  When we talked to the principals of these schools, they observed that they often get volunteers from the local colleges.  These college students tend to be very enthusiastic but have a hard time managing a classroom.  The solution was to have them teach high energy classes such as music and P.E.   I also wonder if you could harness the energy of backpackers using a Taskrabbit/Zaarly like system where teachers could post simple chores/construction tasks they need help with...
Great insight from on the ground, Ben.
check out http://www.1kg.org, more than 1,000 rural schools in China were found and served by travelers.

I believe this great idea could work out quite well providing both parties (backpackers and teachers) do a little preparation work beforehand:-   Backpackers should produce a very basic resume and list of skills in order for teachers to better evaluate their teaching potential-   Teachers should be able to identify their topics of interest to better match what any given backpacker has to offer at a specific time.With a pre-programmed system of slots or units posted outside the classroom, schools could report on their needs and attract the right crowd.
One bias that can be avoided by preparing the ground this way is that of a neo-colonialist trend of thought whereby any young volunteer can teach anything anywhere as well as any teacher in poor countries. This might not be the best approach, depending on the population one has to work with.
My 2 cents.

Amy, James, I agree with your comments. However, is education only about the formal yearly curriculum that needs to have some consistency? Isn't education a process that is happening every time and everywhere, whenever a curious kid asks a question and gets an answer?
interesting, but does that mean if i was there as a student that my teacher would be changing every few weeks.

While I would love to see backpackers do something positive, I don't think this is a realistic option. I studied backpackers in India, and they're a) flaky, b) have no teaching experience, and c) are obsessed with finding "authentic experiences." Ultimately, I think it would be a great experience for the backpackers, and not for the children. There would be no consistency or continuity in the lesson plans.

@Dani - What if they shadowed working individuals within their communities and were accompanies by a facilitator with strict guidelines (as to no interfere). Or, maybe the facilitator, would document real-life experiences, then bring the experiences back to the "classroom" environment?
Thank you all for the comments!

For example, I could imagine a situation where a group of children is assigned to shadow a doctor in a trauma ward. In that case, who would make sure that the students aren't interfering with what the doctor needs to do? How long would they shadow her/him?

allow_students_to_create_and_share_mater.creator: 864a22cc81f3cb672c261f66b4b4ce63

comments.text:
This is a very interesting idea with many far-reaching implications. It deserves to be explored in many ways, in this project and many others.
One of the things I think about when talking about students discussing their problems and issues is: how can we bridge the inevitable gap between the inputs of students and the feedback they receive from the communities around them? Motivated students surely would gladly step up to newly created avenues for expressing themselves, but for such avenues to remain open, these people must see results and actions being undertaken based on their suggestions.
In other words, not only should we allow students to create and share material about their problems and issues, but we should also find ways to allow them to act upon these materials and ideas whilst counting on the support of their communities.

matchbox_learning.description: This builds on Smriti’s inspiration about matchboxes having the most pervasive distribution network/deepest market penetration in rural India. As matchboxes have unused but visible print spaces, perhaps this space could be used as an educational opportunity for children & adults. I.E., by printing a simple picture, the local language word, & its Hindi/English equivalent, matchboxes could improve local language/Hindi/English literacy. These matchbox sides can be easily turned into makeshift flashcards as well.
matchbox_learning.creator: b15ab3f829f0f897fe507ef548741afb

comments.text: It is indeed a great idea, not only for languages, but also for math operations. Even school kids and teachers can create their own learning material according to the subject area they are studying at that particular time, by using matchboxes already discarded. Maybe you can work on the lesson plans. Congrats!!

Some ideas, like this wonderfully resourceful one, may be of the nature of "of course we should do this ... without delay ... why wouldn't we?" There's almost zero extra cost. In itself it's not enough to meet the challenge, but it has the advantage of leverage (effects way beyond cost, since there is essentially no cost) and instant feasibility. Plus, it fits into the culture in a way that can involve the population at large. For example, parents can be involved with their children ... the tool is not isolated within classrooms. There are going to be many complementary ideas needed. This one on its own isn't enough, but it's a great idea. Congrats to submitter on great thinking!
an idea like this might not make an instant impact ... but definitely the easiest to implement and a source for generating curiosity and to create an urge to learn more

which_communication_technologies_are_wid.creator: b15ab3f829f0f897fe507ef548741afb

comments.text: Good point about the demographics. Thanks for providing the qualitative color. To add to your point about mobiles, most are not "smartphones", so an IPhone App, for example, would have limited reach.

Good idea Vincent. Though keep in mind that such stats show nothing about demographics.
I've mentioned elsewhere that TV penetration seems relatively high even in slums (from what I've noted at Mumbai's Dharavi slums).
Radio is still prevalent and has spread to new audiences through FM radios on mobile phones. http://bit.ly/a2vmUD
Re: cellphones  although penetration is growing in India, it's worth noting that young kids don't tend to have them in the context of poverty (primary school age) Some teenagers seem to but still not very often and usually only if they are working and they are relevant to revenue generation. Naturally there are exceptions but I think folks need to get their heads around some of the tendencies here. Like online tools are not going to be relevant unless we are providing the hardware as well. (plus gaps in digital literacy, maintenance issues) Doesn't rule out cellphones + online but I think folks need to be mindful of the context and audience they are designing for.

35th.description: Aflatoun inspires children and youth aged 6–18 years to empower themselves by offering social & financial education in the context of their rights and responsibilities.
35th.creator: 0ebfe65ca16ea82675e4294e27747639

comments.text: Good point Dani. Some of their initiatives are in line with what you are suggesting  like food security in the Philippines and waste management in El Salvador. Could also be great if they also encouraged entrepreneurship training around things like this: http://bit.ly/alLkz9

While this program has a lot of potential, they seem to be taking the same approach to the problem as a myriad of other programs: teach poor people in developing countries to make and sell crafts, which then must be purchased and marketed to first-world countries. The result: an overwhelming (and constantly growing) amount of *stuff* that gluts the market, hopeful for an influx of conscious consumers to purchase it. 
Adding to the problem is the fact that most of these objects, such as candles, jewelry, fancy soaps and accessories, etc., are luxuries, not daily essentials. As such, the market for them fluctuates rapidly, and is based on both economic concerns in the countries they're being marketed in, and the physical attributes of the product (packaging, smell, etc.). As the climate in America - a significant profit center for these products - starts moving more and more towards local economies, and environmental concerns, it's hard to imagine that this trend can sustain itself in the long term. 
That said, I do like the idea of encouraging entrepreneurship as a learning modality. It teaches a wide variety of skills that they can put to use immediately. My question is, can you create a program that does it in such a way that they'll be creating something that will make a larger impact on their daily life?

early_childhood_development_in_a_box_.description: UNICEF has developed an Early Childhood Development kit for distribution to refugee and IDP communities worldwide. The kit includes a classroom in a box for young children. Last fall, a team at the Aspen Design Summit worked to redesign the kit. http://www.designobserver.com/changeobserver/entry.html?entry=11997
early_childhood_development_in_a_box_.creator: be79583f5180581691d1d0be1699b621

comments.text: So necessary. Early childhood development is where we need to start.
This definitely opens up an area for making education more and more portable because that can only help it reach to the remotest of areas.

I would agree with Meena. If UNICEF could abstract the purpose behind the components in the kit, then it can be translated to a local context (reminds me of Nabokov's translation of Alice in Wonderland) which children could better understand. Secondly, it would create more job opportunities in the local market.

I'd certainly support the opinions at Aspen that the kit could be improved through more culturally familiar/relevant games and activities. Plus, give that shipping adds almost 30% to the cost, I wonder if local production could be explored (which could generate local revenue too)
I'd certainly support the opinions at Aspen that the kit could be improved through more culturally familiar/relevant games and activities.

early_childhood_development_in_a_box_.title: Early Childhood Development in a Box

cross_cultural_learning_.description: Could we inspire children by showing them how other cultures have addressed relevant issues? Though they are in different parts of the world some of these communities face the same issues. Some have unique ways of addressing this key issues.
cross_cultural_learning_.creator: bac1161f308485387a307b2bfce571eb

comments.text:
Well you could do it both ways. What is being done in china could be might work for certain communities in Africa, because of certain similarities the community shares. 
If we could connect them through technology or other forms of media it might serve as insight to them.

Well you could do it both ways. What is being done in china could be might work for certain communities in Africa. Because of certain similarities. If we could connect them through technology or other forms of media it might share as insight to them.
by "showing them how other cultures" do you mean connecting them through technology or by simply telling them about them?

cross_cultural_learning_.title: Cross Cultural Learning

a_really_great_teacher.description:
This is the first time I've been on here don't blame me if I mess something up.
My language arts teacher Mr.Jones moved to Indonesia  this last summer. He heard that a long time ago people went to Indonesia, and killed anyone who had an education. Therefor the children in Indonesia didn't have anybody to teach them. Mr.Jones signed up to be a part of the program to bring the education back. He's teaching adults how to be teachers, he's not teaching children directly but indirectly.
a_really_great_teacher.creator: cdbe67f245a1ac76daf14137b11de494

comments.text: how is it disturbing?
this is disturbing and inspiring at the same time

a_really_great_teacher.title: A really great teacher

a_rural_school_uses_many_low_cost_innova.description:
Pragat Shikshan Sanstha(Progressive Education Center) was established in 1986 in a rural town in western India; to convince a four year old girl that school need not be a terrible experience. Maxine Bernsten, the auto-rickshaw driving, educational researcher who came to western study the language, stayed back to create a haven of progressive education. 

http://www.indiaprogressiveeducation.com/
a_rural_school_uses_many_low_cost_innova.creator: 1afb9c415a99e915ab0a6ebfff25039a

comments.text: Will definitely check this out. Thanks

a_rural_school_uses_many_low_cost_innova.title: A rural school uses many low-cost innovations - Pragat Shikshan Sanstha(Progressive Education Center)

py/tuple: What sort of potential do you think this concept has to be a sustainable business?
Very high potential
it's good but it needs a lot of work before going much further
it's got too many open questions right now to say either way
How well do you feel it meets the local needs enterprising schools has identified?  (English language, Math, Libraries, Technology,  Professional Development)
It fulfills really well on the need its chosen to serve
It will help, but other solutions might serve the needs better
It doesn’t really address any of the needs that Enterprising Schools identified.
How well does this concept meet the needs of extreme affordability?
Really well. There are likely ways we can make this concept low cost.
Fairly well. It has good potential for an affordable cost, but more work would need to be done here.
Unsure. I can't yet see the ways it could be made to be low cost, but maybe it's possible.
Doubtful. I just don't believe this can be made low cost.

the_mobile_learner.description: The Mobile Learner makes it easy for students & teachers to create, share, & interact with educational content like books, tutorials, flashcards, & quizzes. The Mobile Learner consists of a re-purposed mobile phone loaded with a free educational software bundle. Content sharing occurs through an online repository (accessible through the cellular network & the Internet), or directly between phones (through memory cards or Bluetooth).
the_mobile_learner.creator: b15ab3f829f0f897fe507ef548741afb

comments.text: Just saw this article "India: land of many cell phones, fewer toilets" in BusinessWeek, and thought it provides some interesting context: http://www.businessweek.com/ap/financialnews/D9J6EKRG2.htm
Thanks Meena. Has been really fun to learn from everyone's perspective and ideas. Really eye opening and inspiring!
Congrats Vincent. It's been fab having you onboard as a inspirer, concepter and collaborator.
Having a full keyboard is essential! Just imagine what the Streetkids of Mumbai could do with this:)
I tot agree with Keane. We should abolish the big digital divide before dong this. It's very futuristic as concept

@Tom: Agreed. There could probably be distinct bundles for Smartphones, Feature Phones, & solely text-based phones. In India, it may make sense to focus on Nokia phones (which share the Symbian Operating System) that dominate there.
@Keane: mobile phone penetration is approaching 50% penetration in India. Also many people (in the developed & developing world) have extra cell phones (due to the frequent trade-up cycle) lying around that could be donated to become Mobile Learners.
it would be nice if this was entirely text (sms) based to ensure that it operated at the lowest common denominator. It could also tap into twitter at this level.
Is there sufficient mobile technology penetration within this audience? Purchasing a phone may be a big barrier...

the_mobile_learner.title: The Mobile Learner

teach_net.description:
An online community that promotes real-life connections between APS teachers, their community and the wider community. A service that provides tangible and targeted response to need.
Yes, yes, I know, computers, electricity, internet connections = problem, but just hear me out :-)
teach_net.creator: d3d7eaed605c49b6d7fa0ffa4e4d642d

comments.text: Cool stuff!

Awesome! I really like the foursquare concept and it could be a good way of engaging people for this concept. This triggered a thought; we are constantly questioning the viability of computers due to the expensive nature, need for mains power and wired connectivity, is it a more realistic to start suggesting smart-phones as an alternative. In terms of infrastructure we could aim for sponsorship from NGOs and the Government for transmissions masts and then give teachers a smart-phone. I bet there's loads of iPhone 3Gs' sitting idle now :-) Just a thought but there is something there...

Alex  what a great collaborator you are!  crediting everyone and building upon various input across other's concepts, inspirations and comments. I'm a huge fan of the Barefoot College: http://bit.ly/dxt4nf Am wondering if there is some way you could incentivise teachers to participate  along the lines of Foursquare badges, etc?

Not entirely related but something that I found really interesting whilst prepping this idea:
http://www.barefootcollege.org/sol_approach.asp

sticker_albums_as_an_educational_tool.description: Before and during the 2010 World Cup, millions of children and adults alike collected and traded stickers with photos of famous World Cup players. Entire new communities of sticker traders appeared overnight, interacting in many ways and sharing with each other their collectibles. How can we create educational opportunities with activities like these, which inspire collaboration and can simply be fun to do?
sticker_albums_as_an_educational_tool.creator: 558446cc723a5ad8bc329a2528a5b36c

I like the suggestion that the stickers could denote merit in some way (similarly incentivising to Four Square badges) so that students are motivated into actions/learning to earn stickers.

what_kind_of_tools_.description: What kind of tools are needed for such schools? What do students & parents from these backgrounds seek from education? What about the tradeoff between income & a potential earning member lost due to a member availing education? What are the return from being educated & how is it measured? What is being desired & what is gained from education in similar schools in India?
what_kind_of_tools_.creator: af84756089a281f201342a5968a40d5f

comments.text: Hey Neeraj, there are some great examples of things that exist in your post here... i'm worried that people won't see them all. Can you post the RBI and TATA examples separately (with images) so they're more prominently displayed? Thanks!

Good point on recognizing the tradeoffs for poorer families between education & income, and thus the importance of making sure that education is interesting and applicable to kids daily realities. There are definitely opportunities to make sure children can learn, while improving their ability to earn.

what_kind_of_tools_.title: What kind of tools ?

global_lesson_sharing_platform_moodle_to.description:
This platform allows people to share lessons around the world and bridges the gap between learning content creation and delivery.
The inclusion of MoOCH in Moodle 2.0 provides a globally available (>45000 Moodle sites exist), free platform for people that create learning content to find and share lessons, courses and content with others. Moodle itself makes learning collaborative, effective and fun.
global_lesson_sharing_platform_moodle_to.creator: 9fe3a0ac960996c395ac8c48432b40fd

comments.text: This is a fascinating concept, imagine an educator in India being able to write a course that would be accessible in remote Australia, the UK and Ghana simultaneously.  Not only would the cultural exchange be enlightening, the possiblity for bridging the gaps between nations through the education of our children may well have astounding results.  With this Moodle/Mooch platform resources are shared across borders cutting course building time and increasing teaching time. A definite plus for all educators and their students. I too would use this tool!

global_lesson_sharing_platform_moodle_to.title: Global Lesson Sharing Platform - Moodle to the power of MOOCH

learning_by_doing_microdocumentaries_lea.creator: 9f926880e84ea0eb301decf03d398f55

comments.text:
Hi Vincent, thank you very much for your comment. I answer to your points below.
"Costs of recording + production + distribution + display seem rather high currently".
- Any estimate? Costs of recording (recording would be done by teachers and children) + production (ditto) + distribution (ditto) + display (see affordable initiatitives proposed here for the acquisition of recording, production and display devices). Furthermore I would say that acquisition, not recording+production+distribution+display costs, are relatively high at the beginning but redeemable.
"In the future, as these costs decrease, the concept may become more viable".
- This is obvious. As they learn they would optimize production costs over time.
"In the meantime, initiatives that rely on lower cost mediums, lIike http://bit.ly/b0NsO5, may make more sense for providing the same benefit".
- The initiative that you point out to is great, thank you. I will build on it and evaluate the rest of initiatives at the end of this week. I agree with the idea that innovation is about "sense", but also about facts. Both mine and Amanda's initiative are comparable, but mostly compatible and coherent. Amanda's initiative simply do not propose the production of minidocumentaries and the connection of APS with other schools all over the world. 
Thank you again, let's keep on building on the 40 concepts!

Costs of recording + production + distribution + display seem rather high currently. In the future, as these costs decrease, the concept may become more viable. In the meantime, initiatives that rely on lower cost mediums, like http://bit.ly/b0NsO5, may make more sense for providing the same benefit.

learning_by_doing_microdocumentaries_lea.title: Learning-by-doing microdocumentaries - Learn how other children did it

comments.text:
Meena- using local materials would be ideal. Also, if you got the local community involved in building the school, seems like you'd get more buy-in/commitment, too.
That said, I like the shipping container ideas as well. They could be set up, ready to go, and then dropped on site as a sort of temporary/initial schoolhouse. Plus, it's reusing something that's just piling up in docks all across the globe.

Interesting to note that this idea has been featured 3 times now. Am a tad hesitant about it given that many contexts of development have very hot climates  even if the container had no roof it would be super hot. I'm also more in favour of initiatives which use local materials... but perhaps that's just me.

education_in_craft_livelihood_security_e.description: With skills that are unique to, and prevalent within, the villages of India, craft production is a practical and effective source of employment. Hence, use of craft as a mechanism to convert the disasters into an economic and developmental opportunity can lure kids towards schooling and education.
education_in_craft_livelihood_security_e.creator: 28890c0b3a775ebd22755c0a1a35b9f4

comments.text: Yep, I agree the labour/abuse thing could be a challenge, I wonder whether an organisation could audit the schools and run the supply chain of materials to the schools and distribution of craft out of the schools to put some controls in place. Could be open to corruption though i agree. However, if it means more kids end up at school learning new skills for even a part of the day then perhaps it's still a success, despite what our western sensibilities about children and work might think? Challenging problem...

A concept that has been tried in a number of places. The biggest issue is that the school/business has to be very very careful of not crossing the line into forced child labor. In my humble opinion, school should be fun and childlike, not work.

It could definitely be modified that way paul, if part of that money being earned is going for the education then it will draw more entrepreneur towards this scheme, as well as encourage parents to send there kids to school which is one of the major problems in rural education (unwilling parents).

Maybe kids could learn a craft while they are at school then begin to sell their goods through the school, the income from their craft could then go to pay for their education? The entrepreneur who's running the school would have an interest in the success of both the craft and the teaching and the kids would benefit through both skills that are immediately useful (craft) and skills which may take longer to see benefits (literacy / maths etc.)

education_in_craft_livelihood_security_e.title: Education in Craft = Livelihood Security = Elimination of poverty

23rd.description: Global content combining education + entertainment gets adapted for wider uptake.
23rd.creator: 0ebfe65ca16ea82675e4294e27747639

comments.text: Wow Dalli  that's a great insight about the power of mainstream TV to highlight inclusiveness and acceptance.

Hey Meena, great inspiration. Thank you. The ability of the muppets to be tailored to address local issues and challenges is remarkable. In South Africa we have a version called Takalani Sesame. "Takalani" means "Be happy" in the local Venda language. Here the muppets converse in all 11 of South Africa's official languages. Takalani Sesame also made history in 2002 when it introduced the first HIV positive muppet on the planet, Kami. In a country with one of the highest incidences of HIV/AIDS the benefits of this tailoring to local relevance cannot be underestimated.

Hi Mayowa  I guess we're all figuring this out as we go. Seems to me that for the most part we're providing inspiration for now and then can extend into concepting in the next round. Naturally as most of us are creative/design types, it's difficult to hold ourselves back from imagining 'what could be.' ;^) Sorry... I don't understand the benefit of what you're suggesting below. Better you explain it more fully in the next (concepting) phase perhaps.

Hi Meena. It just occurred to me that I might be doing this wrong - I keep coming up with ideas while it seems we should just be pointing each other to what exists presently (for now, at this present stage of the process). Is that your understanding? I ask coz that's what you seem to be doing....

Building on this - and I know this may be a bit way out -  but can the producers of Sesame Street produce the shows in such a way that they only film the muppets and then allow themselves and others to insert whatever background or humans are required for each location? That way the characters can have the same interaction against a Mumbai or New York backdrop. I know it sounds crazy (even to me) but I'm putting it out there for your comments...
absolutely! This is a great provocation, not just because of how well sesame street adapts globally, but also for the specific solutions to make it work -- like the push cart/tv/dvd.

23rd.title: Tailoring for Local Relevance

lab_in_a_box.description: Inspired by the FOSS (Full Option Science System) of LHS, Berkeley and triggered by insufficient science labs in most APS especially at the middle school level, the 'Lab in a Box' is an effort to facilitate more  hands-on science learning.
lab_in_a_box.creator: 9169501ba9df226522e4566acad55c53

comments.text: Good idea. You should explore the Science on Wheels concept pioneered by Agastya Foundation in India. The guy who runs in also a Ashoka Fellow. There is a good overlap as well opportunities to collaborate. If we can put together a series of "boxes" based on particular concepts and ship them over to schools for a pilot, would be a great start. If that hits the mark, it would be mostly be a question of scale and reach.

This is a great idea. I could see this extending over time, to different ages or different subject areas. I bet an organization like agastya could put out something like this, given their experiences in teaching hands on science. Would be fun to think about new distribution models that create local entrepreneurs. Is there a door to door salesman? Is there a subscription service that sends you a new box every month? Maybe it's kind of like Tupperware parties, where school communities come together to learn about a varied product line and see what's needed for their school? The entrepreneur could get commission on the sales... Anyway, great idea, fun to think about how it might turn real!

comments.text: The KidZui Plugin in Firefox browser can be starting point. Its very innovative and targeted to kids.

Arturo,These kids have the remarkable ability to ferret out thier own emergent solutions, while overcoming huge obstacles in their daily lives. Hopefully the slum wall internet provides the initial bridge for them to connect with quality teachers who care.

Avi, 
While I think it is a novel idea to disseminate access points to the Internet. In Education, it is important to design for the Learner. This implies a carefully designed and curated set of tools that are integrated into curriculum where learning objectives and outcomes can be measured and effective remediation can occur.
Simply placing access points may not necessarily provide the solution. But it is definetely part of a strategy if you were to think of strategic partnerships that could create/ curate/ commission shell websites that guide Learners into content.

comments.text:
Teachers might not reduce themselves to a 'supervise only' role. Online media in the transfer of knowledge is superior to classroom teaching, then what is the opportunity of the classroom as opposed to saying their is no classroom. 
Teachers can learn in the same way as the students making stronger teachers and people interested in teaching, educate themselves to do so. The class could be a discussion between pupils about what they learned via their online explorations, where they learn the content by themselves and discuss in class. The teacher is still very important in the education,no longer the provider, but still the curator.
Collective experience is great learning tool! Great idea!

But, when we speak of education interventions... we think of one or ten classrooms at a time.

comments.text: @yanis Admittedly its current implementation is a "1st world" thing. f4_fundamentals_for_computer_literacy.description: Many of the affordable private schools (APS) in Hyderabad have realized the importance in technological education from an early age.  In an attempt to fill this need and make their schools more competitive many APS owners have invested in computer labs and even in Internet connection for those labs.  The educational foresight, however, tends to stop there, leaving computer labs idle and children still not computer-literate.  There are not enough teachers who are computer literate themselves and even those who are, are not trained in how to appropriately utilize computers to advance technological literacy and education as a whole.   The concept is therefore to develop a replicable, moderator based computer education curriculum for class 4 through 10.
f4_fundamentals_for_computer_literacy.creator: b1ff727e00c9630f6f911ccb398a0bab

comments.text: It is very effective to involve the parents and community.  That triangle of students, parents, community is one key component to this computer literacy program being successful and sustainable.

I really like this idea. As we all know tech, web-based start-ups have a great potential to become a source of wealth for many people with scarce resources, as you can bootstrap your business, thus costs of failure are low. To include this curriculum early in children education have, in my opinion, two advantages:
1. It provides them with tools for the future development of web-based projects if they decide to2. It provides early in their education with the necessary values that they will need for a wise and respectful use of the internet applications
Also, there is pre-existing "computer basics" content available online, much of it free, that could be leveraged for this curriculum.

Ilana, good point about creating a framework to ensure that schools/students get the most out of technology investments. And I like how you mapped out the curriculum around meaningful projects, rather than rote functionality review, so students are engaged and productive. It'd also be great if students were given outside-of-class access to the computer lab, so they could engage in further self-directed exploration/projects, and to maximize use of the computer facilities.
Craig, definitely see the merit in vendor neutrality, though we should also look at which applications are most used in India.
As the curriculum assumes the presence of computers, its production & distribution cost can be further lowered by using digital instead of print media (i.e. digital curriculum that can be transferred by dvd/usb/disc/internet/etc, viewed on the computer, and only printed if necessary).

I like this literacy plan and believe it will be effective.  We can add even more value to this by making the plan vendor-neutral.  For example, in Ilana's case, naming Microsoft products not only assumes this vendor's suite of applications but also MS operating systems.
Continuing with this example, Ilana's plan can substitute the words "Microsoft Word, PowerPoint, and Excel" with "productivity applications, including a word processor, presentation software and spreadsheets."  
I bring this up because we have been reconditioning pc's and laptops with either MSOS (WinXP or newer) or Linux (usually Ubuntu).  In both cases, we include OpenOffice.org's application suite pre-configured to use the most popular file formats.  These configurations have been well-received by high school and colleges students.
The advantages are two-fold:- initial costs are driven down further- computer literacy isn't vendor-dependent
Thanks again, Ilana, for a compelling idea.-Craig

f4_fundamentals_for_computer_literacy.title: F4: Fundamentals for Computer Literacy

comments.text: This idea looks interesting. Few things to consider,1. Most villages do not have access to electricity. So this device needs to be paired with low-cost display and manually or hand-powered.2. Re-cycled TV sets are provided to villages. These can double up for community news/entertainment.
Brilliant!

Yorgos,
While this is an interesting artifact, it assumes that classrooms can have TVs. Many classrooms are not at all what you could consider classrooms, they may not have walls or a roof or chairs at all.
Another thing about this device is that it assumes that learning is passive, whereas if the past 10 years have told us anything (ironically with Wikipedia as an example), it is multidirectional. The learner can become a content generator too.

8th.description: By creating a youth-led, education-focused radio station, can we we empower children to teach + learn?
8th.creator: 0ebfe65ca16ea82675e4294e27747639

comments.text: Also, you may want to check out the website itself : http://communityradio.in/

I found an actual example of a child run program in India.  http://communityradio.in/priyanka.htm"Child Radio Reporter is about lending an ear to underprivileged children as they talk about hardships they have suffered, voice their grievances and question the authorities for their negligence."A program such as this could be adapted for educational purposes

Multi media educational tools are very effective as a learning device and should be positioned as part of the core teaching learning process. Schools perceive multimedia educational tools as an add-on to the conventional teaching-learning process and are unable to transact and build upon the educational value of these tools. Hence school management needs to be educated on using innovative multimedia tools as a part of the regular curriculum.

8th.title: Youth-led Radio Station
